title: Lisboa OSF as a web font?
content:
I am thinking of replace a Myriad font with Lisboa OSF on a website.  
How do you think Lisboa's performance would be on a website?

Is it even worth it? Will the attention to a more flavorful font be noticeable??

Interested in any opinions. :-)

Also, I've noticed that at small sizes, the Uppercase "R" is shorter than other letters... why is this so?
author: wnf

comments.content: This is due to [hinting](http://web.archive.org/web/20141128021423/http:/typophile.com/wiki/hinting) or the font's lack thereof. At small sizes most fonts will get wonky on screen. Only those with superior hinting will do well without specially designed bitmaps.

Stephen... man you know your typography.  
(So, maybe you will give me some further "hints." ;-)

Any help as to a font to replace Myriad on a website that may have some flavoring would be very welcome.

Thanks  
wnf
How large? I highly recommend sticking with HTML text for anything under 18pt. Lisboa will work just fine as a GIF at 18+.

This is good advice.

Trying to get typography to size properly across browsers and systems is a task even with great css.... hence, my try at a small gif or jpeg for 16pt type.

I think youve made a good point... thanks!

Actually, Peter, I was asking wnf (the original poster) what his settings were since he found it unsatisfactory.

\> _Miguel, I know Stephen’s problem with the “r” (and he’s not alone) but I wonder exactly what distracts you in the “M”, “O” and “W” (and in which sizes/weights)?_

In reverse order of (alphabetic) appearance, the Ugly, the Wide and the Widest :^)

Well, I'm not sure exactly what you're saying about which. I do realize the "M" is wide in every size/weight, but in a bitmap font it's not always possible to make symmetrical letters an ideal width, especially if you want to keep certainly corners sharp (one pixel). Also in bitmap fonts you have to mind the relationships of the various sizes, and you have to "snap" the glyphs in larger sizes to the wider possibility so you leave yourself enough room in the smaller sizes. You'll notice how some letters (like the "T") have quite different proportions across the sizes.

The sacrifices in a bitmap font can be strenuous and befuddling.  
Look at the "v" in 16 PPEM Georgia!

hhp
